title: Cope

thumbnail.alt_text: Half circle of fabric, embroidered with Virgin Mary, saints, prophets, and plant motif.

description: The production of textiles for churches—hangings, altar frontals, and liturgical vestments—was a thriving industry in Europe from the twelfth century through the eighteenth century. Among the finest ecclesiastical vestments is this resplendent velvet cope, a semicircular cloak worn as an outer garment in processions or during special ceremonies by a priest or bishop. The elegant needlework was called opus anglicanum (English work). Surrounding the cope’s central image of the Assumption of the Virgin, rendered in silk and gold threads, are seraphim standing on wheels, thistles, fleurs-de-lis, and double-headed eagles—all connected by tendrils animated by spangles. Old Testament prophets and New Testament saints with their attributes alternate on the orphrey band, which runs the full width of the work. Saint Paul is depicted on the hood, which rests on the back of the cope, while an image of God holding an orb decorates the morse, or closure. The brown-velvet ground is an unusual color for vestments of this style; it may have faded from purple or crimson.
medium_display: Silk cut and voided velvet, linen appliqué, silk and gilt metallic thread embroidery, and metal spangles
publication_history:
Burlington Fine Arts Club, Exhibition of English Embroidery Executed Prior to the Middle of the Seventeenth Century (London: Burlington Fine Arts Club, 1905), 10, 56-57, plate 10 (Ill.).

Sotheby’s, Wilkinson & Hodge, The Collection of 15th Century Vestments from Whalley Abbey, sales cat., June 23, 1922,  (London: Sotheby’s, Wilkinson & Hodge, 1922), 10, Lot 41, frontispiece (Ill.).

Christa C. Mayer Thurman, "Recent Acquisitions: An English Cope," Bulletin of the Art Institute of Chicago LXVII, 2 (Mar./Apr. 1973): 4–5 (Ill.).

Christa C. Mayer Thurman, Raiment for the Lord's Service: A Thousand Years of Western Vestments (Chicago: Art Institute of Chicago, 1975), 134–7, (Ill.).

Christa C. Mayer Thurman, Textiles in The Art Institute of Chicago (Chicago: Art Institute of Chicago, 1992), 42–3, 50, 144 (Ill.). 

Art Institute of Chicago: The Essential Guide (Chicago: Art Institute of Chicago, 1993), 229 (Ill.).

Clare Brown, Glyn Daview, and M.A. Michael, eds., English Medieval Embroidery: Opus Anglicanum (New Haven and London: Yale University Press in association with the Victoria and Albert Museum, 2016), 32.
exhibition_history:
London, Burlington Fine Arts Club, Exhibition of English Embroidery Executed Prior to the Middle of the Sixteenth Century, 1905.

Art Institute of Chicago, Selected Textile Acquisitions Since 1967, July 10, 1972–Apr. 30, 1973.

Art Institute of Chicago, Raiment for the Lord's Service–A Thousand Years of Western Vestments, Nov. 15, 1975–Jan. 18, 1976.

Art Institute of Chicago, Agnes Allerton Gallery, Vestments and Liturgical Textiles from the Permanent Collection, July 27–Oct. 9, 1983.

Art Institute of Chicago, Department of European Decorative Arts, Gunsaulus Hall, European Textile Masterpieces from Coptic Times through the 19th Century (in conjunction with), Sept. 27, 1989–Jan. 22, 1990.

Art Institute of Chicago, Department of European Decorative Arts, Gunsaulus Hall, Textile Masterpieces from the Art Institute of Chicago's Collection (displayed in conjunction with) Feb. 17–May 10, 1993.

Art Institute of Chicago, Elizabeth F. Cheney and Agnes Allerton Textile Galleries, Gloria in Excelsis Deo: Heralding a Vestment Collection, Sept. 11, 1996–Jan. 12, 1997.

Art Institute of Chicago, Department of European Decorative Arts, Gunsaulus Hall, Aug. 19- Dec. 31, 1998.

Art Institute of Chicago, Department of European Decorative Arts, Gunsaulus Hall, Nov. 6, 2002- Apr. 22, 2003.

provenance_text: Whalley Abbey, Whalley, Lancashire, England, before 1537 [this and the following according to Sotheby’s 1922; the Abbey of Whalley was closed 1537]; to Sir John Towneley (1473–1540), Towneley Hall, Burnley, Lancashire, England, from 1537; by descent through the Towneley family; John Towneley (1806–1878); by descent to his daughter, Lady O’Hagan (born Alice Townely, 1846–1921) [Burlington Fine Arts Club 1905, 10]; sold Sotheby, London [as property of Lord O’Hagan (Maurice Towenely O’Hagan, 3rd Baron O’Hagan, 1882–1961), Pyrgo Park, Essex], June 23, 1922, lot 41. Blumka Gallery, NY, by Mar. 30, 1970 [Incoming permanent receipt RX7934, Apr. 2, 1970; copy in curatorial object file]; sold to the Art Institute of Chicago, 1971.
